description: From Middle English straglen, of uncertain origin.

entries.meaning: An outlier; something that has strayed beyond the normal limits.
examples: Nevertheless there is a straggle of pungent sense in it, â€” like the outskirts of lightning, seen in that dismally wet weather, which the Royal Party had.

verbs.description: straggle (third-person singular simple present straggles, present participle straggling, simple past and past participle straggled)

entries.meaning: To stray, rove, or wander from a normal course and others of its kind.
examples: He straggled away from the crowd and went off on his own.

entries.meaning: To act in a disorderly and irregular way
examples: They came between Scylla and Charybdis and the straggling rocks.
